title: Accessibility statement
heading1: Accessibility statement for ‘Stopping a probate application’ service
paragraph1: This accessibility statement applies to Stop a grant of probate - GOV.UK (opens in a new tab)
paragraph2: This service allows users to apply to stop an application for a grant of representation (also known as probate) online.
paragraph3: This website is run by HM Courts and Tribunals. We want as many people as possible to be able to use this website, so we have designed it to be accessible. For example, that means you should be able to:
list1-item1: change colours, contrast levels and fonts
list1-item2: zoom in up to 300% without the text spilling off the screen
list1-item3: navigate most of the website using just a keyboard
list1-item4: navigate most of the website using speech recognition software
list1-item5: listen to most of the website using a screen reader (including the most recent versions of JAWS, NVDA and VoiceOver)
paragraph4: We’ve also made the website text as simple as possible to understand.
paragraph5: AbilityNet (opens in a new tab) has advice on making your device easier to use if you have a disability.
paragraph6: We know some parts of this website are not fully accessible:
list2-item1: The address lookup tool’s results do not magnify on some tablets. This a constraint within some tablet browsers.
list2-item2: There are outstanding accessibility issues outside of this service, in the government payments service, which may result in accessible technology users having difficulties using this area.
paragraph7: If you need information on this website in a different format like accessible PDF, large print, easy read or braille, contact:
paragraph8: We’ll consider your request and get back to you within 10 working days.
heading3a: Contacting us by phone or visiting us in person
paragraph8a: We provide a text relay service for people who are D/deaf, hearing impaired or have a speech impediment.
paragraph8b: Our offices have audio induction loops, or if you contact us before your visit we can arrange a British Sign Language (BSL) interpreter.
heading4: Reporting accessibility problems with this website
paragraph9: We’re always looking to improve the accessibility of this website. If you find any problems that are not listed on this page or think we’re not meeting accessibility requirements, contact us using the phone number above.
paragraph10: We’ll consider your request and get back to you within 10 working days.
paragraph11: The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) is responsible for enforcing the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (the ‘accessibility regulations’). If you’re not happy with how we respond to your complaint, contact the Equality Advisory and Support Service (EASS) (opens in a new window).
heading7: Technical information about this website’s accessibility
paragraph15: HMCTS is committed to making its websites accessible, in accordance with the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018.
paragraph16: The website is partially compliant with the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines version 2.1 AA standard (opens in a new window) due to the non-compliances listed below.
paragraph17: The content listed below is non-accessible for the following reasons. We haven’t been able to verify that we are fully compliant in the following areas, due to constraints with our internal testing tools:
list6-item2: There are no headings in the PDF documents.
heading10: Content that’s not within the scope of the accessibility regulations
paragraph18: PDFs, documents and attachments to email notifications published before 23 September 2018 may not meet accessibility standards. For example, they may not be structured so they’re accessible to a screen reader.
heading10-2: Third party content that’s under someone else’s control
paragraph19: Pages and websites that are linked to and from the probate service may not be fully accessible. These include:
list7-item1: External pages hosting PDF documents for example Form PA15 (opens in a new tab)
list7-item2: the login pages – check the HMCTS Access accessibility statement (opens in a new tab) for more information
list7-item3: payment pages – check the GOV.UK Pay accessibility statement (opens in a new tab) for more information
list7-item4: emails sent by GOV.UK Notify – check the GOV.UK Notify accessibility statement (opens in a new tab) for more information
list7-item5: instruction pages on GOV.UK, for example When a death is reported to a coroner - GOV.UK (opens in a new tab)
list7-item6: The webchat application which provides live service support for users
heading11: What we’re doing to improve accessibility
paragraph20:
We continually run automated accessibility testing as part of our development practices and resolve issues before websites and new functionality is released. We use Pa11y and Axe with our quality assurance processes.

This website is continually tested using accessibility software. Any new features which are introduced will also be tested internally or with the Digital Accessibility Centre (DAC).
paragraph21: This statement was prepared in March 2025. It was last updated on 7 April 2025
paragraph22: The ‘Apply for probate’ was last tested by the internal Accessibility Testing Centre of Excellence (ATCoE) team in September 2024.
